Award.AwardTitle: AGS-PRF: Quantifying the Sources of Atmospheric Ice Nuclei from Biomass Burning and Fossil Fuel Combustion Aerosol
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will allow a postdoctoral researcher the opportunity to study the sources and composition of atmospheric ice nuclei. Ice nuclei are small particles that are especially efficient at forming ice crystals in clouds. Very few particles in the atmosphere have this property, but their effect on clouds and precipitation is large. The main aspect of this award will be the measurement of ice nuclei that originates from combustion sources, such as agricultural burning, wildfires, and vehicle pollution. The number of ice nuclei and the ability of the particles to form ice crystals will be studied. The end result of the project will be a better understanding of the role of particles from combustion sources in the cloud system, and an improved tool that will be incorporated into numerical models from the cloud scale to the global scale. The researcher will also promote cross-disciplinary research between the atmospheric and biological sciences, as well as mentor a summer intern in order to enhance undergraduate training and learning.

The ice nucleation activity of carbonaceous combustion aerosol is poorly constrained, with conflicting results from both field and laboratory studies. This work will address this shortcoming through the direct sampling of combustion aerosols in the field, and associated laboratory work. The main instruments to be used are the Colorado State University (CSU) continuous flow diffusion chamber (CFDC) to determine the number concentration of ice nuclei and the single particle soot photometer (SP2) to selectively remove refractory black carbon. Biosamplers will also be used to determine the contribution of biological particles and organic materials. Select particles will be further assessed using Scanning Electron Microscopy coupled to Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy (SEM-EDS). The specific objectives of the project are to: 1) conduct laboratory experiments to test the technique of coupling the SP2 instrument to the CFDC, 2) measure ice nuclei from controlled winter wheat burns in Oklahoma, 3) conduct sampling of ice nuclei from wildfires in Colorado, 4) perform sampling of fossil fuel combustion near highways in Colorado, and 5) modify or create new parameterizations for cloud to global scale models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ice nucleation on aerosol particles is a fundamental process that impacts climate by modifying cloud radiative properties and influences the hydrological cycle via precipitation. Despite this impact, ice formation in the atmosphere remains one of the least understood atmospheric processes and represents a major barrier for predictions of climate change. One reason for this low understanding is that ice concentrations are low (only ~1 in 105 particles in the atmosphere nucleate ice), making it challenging to identify both the composition and sources of ambient ice nucleating particles.

Black carbon, commonly known as soot, is formed during the incomplete combustion of carbon-based fuels from sources such as vehicles, industry, and wildfires. Since it is emitted directly into the atmosphere in large quantities, it has been recognized as a potential ice nucleating particle. Unfortunately, previous estimates of the impact of black carbon on ice nucleating particle populations are in conflict, with estimates of its impact ranging from no effect to rivaling the well-known ice nucleating particle mineral dust. One reason for this conflict is that few quantitative methods to determine the direct contribution of black carbon to ice nucleating particles concentrations exist, and they have not been deployed in the field.

This work has field-deployed, for the first time, a new technique to directly determine the contribution of black carbon to ice nucleating particles. This technique was taken to the Colorado State University Powerhouse Facility’s Engines Laboratory, to sample the exhaust from an off-road diesel. In addition, an atmospheric aging simulator, the Potential Aerosol Mass chamber, was used to determine if aging the particles in the exhaust an equivalent of 1.5 days in the atmosphere affected their ice nucleating potential. Finally, this new technique was integrated into the Colorado State University Mobile Laboratory, which was driven to prescribed burns and wildfires (see image, photo credit: Barb Van Syke). Here, the contribution of black carbon in prescribed burn and wildfire smoke to ice nucleating particles concentrations was determined. From these combined studies, new parameterizations were developed for use in global chemical transport and climate models.

This research has established that diesel exhaust, even when it has been aged in the atmosphere for 1.5 days, does not contribute to ice nucleating particle concentrations. Furthermore, despite high correlations between ice nucleating particles and black carbon from both prescribed burns and wildfires, black carbon does not directly contribute to more than 10% of the ice nucleating particles in these smoke plumes. These results were implemented into a chemical transport model, which indicate that using previous estimations of the contribution of black carbon to ice nucleating particle concentrations may drastically overestimate their importance in modulating cloud radiative properties. This surprising result has large implications for global climate modelers, and, therefore, our predictions of global climate change.
